summary: Howard J. Osborn was the Director of Security for the CIA. The documents indicate his involvement in key personnel assignments within the Office of Security in 1965, including reassignments of Arthur C. Sheridan, James W. McCord, Jr., and James P. O'Connell, Jr. He was also involved in covert security approvals, such as for Robert West Pugh under Project HBILKA/JBGREED in 1966. Later, in 1975, Osborn testified about CIA mail opening projects like SR POINTER and West Pointer, cooperative arrangements with Customs, and the fact that some operations involved opening mail without explicit authorization. He also testified regarding activities of the CIA's Office of Security, including electronic surveillance, physical surveillance, Watergate contacts, covert informers, mail intercepts, and cooperation with local police.
significance: Howard J. Osborn's significance in the JFK context stems from his role as Director of Security for the CIA and his involvement in various sensitive operations, including mail intercepts and personnel assignments. His testimony regarding these activities provides insight into the CIA's operational practices during the period surrounding the assassination.
